data.title: Guide to Picasso's Barcelona ~ Trace the Steps of Picasso's Youth
data.meta_description: Retrace the footsteps of Picasso's youth in Barcelona: where he lived, his studios and the cafes, bars and art galleries that formed his world.
data.text:
‚ÄúBarcelona the beautiful and wise, where I left so many things hanging on the altar of happiness‚Ä¶‚Äù

~ Pablo Picasso, 1936

In this article we‚Äôll explore the Barcelona of Picasso‚Äôs youth. Discover the places he lived, the studios where he painted early masterpieces and the cafes and art galleries that formed his world.

Barcelona at the turn of the 20th Century

During the period in which Picasso lived in Barcelona the city was undergoing dramatic changes. The Eixample neighborhood was being built, local industry was booming and it was becoming an increasingly cosmopolitan European city. Beginning in 1860 engineer Ildefonso Cerd√° had introduced the reform and expansion of Barcelona beyond its medieval walls. Now known as the Cerd√° Plan, the project urbanized the area surrounding the old town of Barcelona to reach nearby villages such as Gr√†cia.

1. Passeig d‚ÄôIsabel II, 4, Ground Floor

Pablo Picasso was born in M√°laga in 1881, where his father had been a teacher at the San Telmo art school. The Ruiz y Picasso family arrived in Barcelona by boat in 1895, when Pablo was thirteen years old. His father, Jos√© Ruiz y Blasco, had been offered a post to teach figure drawing at the Llotja de Barcelona art academy. Pablo was accepted as a student at the art academy shortly after their arrival. The family‚Äôs first lodging was on Passeig d‚ÄôIsabel II, near the port and across the street from the Llotja building that housed the art school. Pablo had a younger sister called Lola and another sister Conchita who had tragically died of diphtheria in 1895. The young Picasso‚Äôs first painting in Barcelona was from the roof of this building: Rooftop of Les Cases d‚ÄôEn Xifr√© dated by the artist October 4th 1895.

2. Carrer de Cristina, 3 2n 2¬™

The Picassos soon moved to a larger flat nearby on the second floor of Carrer de Cristina number 3. The entrance was on Carrer Llauder, 4 on the corner. Another example of Picasso‚Äôs early work in Barcelona is his painting of the nearby Barceloneta beach dating from 1896. While Picasso is now known as a pioneer of Cubism and modern art, it is important to remember that during his childhood and youth his studies were guided by strict traditional artistic disciplines.

üêâ Skip the line and save money on top attractions like Park G√ºell and La Sagrada Fam√≠lia with the Barcelona Pass

In the summer of 1896 the family moved to Carrer de la Merc√® in the Gothic Quarter, near the church dedicated to La Merc√® (the patron saint of Barcelona).

3. Carrer de la Merc√®, 3, 2n 1¬™

***

The building no longer exists because it was demolished to make way for the square in front of La Merc√® church. Picasso drew this pastel and pencil work of the dome of the church of La Merc√® in 1897. This photo from 1900 shows an exuberant young Picasso with his friends Angel Fern√°ndez de Soto and Carlos Casagemas on the rooftop of Carrer de la Merc√®, 3.

4. Carrer de la Plata, 4

***

In 1896, Picasso‚Äôs father rented a studio on the top floor of this building for his 14 year old son. Picasso shared the studio with Manuel Pallar√©s, a friend from Horta de Sant Juan who he had met in the Fine Arts School. Picasso maintained a close friendship with Pallar√©s throughout his life. It was in this studio that Picasso painted Science and Charity (1897) at age 15, now in the Museu Picasso de Barcelona.

5. Carrer dels Escudellers Blancs, 1 or 2

***

In 1899, Picasso used a new studio in Carrer dels Escudellers Blancs, situated near Placa Reial. On the same floor as Picasso had his studio, there was a workshop making women‚Äôs lingerie. Jaime Sabart√©s, his friend and personal secretary, recounted that ‚Äòduring his moments of leisure, Picasso liked to make the eyelets for corsets on the machines.‚Äô

Carrer de la Riera de Sant Joan, 17

His next studio in 1900 was at 17, Riera de Sant Joan, a street that no longer exists due to the construction work started on Via Laietana in 1907. Picasso shared the small flat with his best friend Carles Casagemas, who he first met at Els Quatre Gats. The two young artists are said to have painted the walls with bookshelves, tables, armchairs, a sideboard with fruit, flowers and coins and even an attractive maid. In late 1900, Picasso made his life changing first trip to Paris accompanied by Casagemas. In 1901 Casagemas tragically shot himself at L‚ÄôHippodrome Caf√© because of an unrequited love for Germaine Pichot, a dancer at the Moulin Rouge. The tragic death of his friend gave impetus to Picasso‚Äôs melancholy Blue Period. Picasso painted La Vie(Life), currently at the Cleveland Museum of Art, Ohio, from this studio in May 1903. This painting, in which Casagemas is depicted along with other figures is viewed as among his most important works from the Blue Period.

6. Carrer Nou de la Rambla, 10 (formerly called Conde del Asalto)

After his first two trips to Paris, Picasso shared a new studio in 1902 with the sculptor Angel Fernandez de Soto and the painter Josep Rocarol in the Raval neighborhood, roughly across the street from Palau G√ºell. The studio was situated at the top of the building and Picasso painted roof terraces and several works from his Blue Period. The Eden Concert, a variety hall, was just next door. The venue was popular with Picasso and his friends and he drew sketches of the cupl√© singers (cupl√© was a popular risqu√© Spanish theatre song style at the time.) After his third trip to Paris in the winter of 1903, Picasso returned once again to the studio he had shared with Casagemas at Riera de Sant Joan, 17.

7. Carrer del Comer√ß, 28

***

Picasso‚Äôs last studio in Barcelona (1904) was lent him by the sculptor Pau Gargallo. This building housed three great artists almost at the same time. In addition to Picasso and Gargallo, the painter Isidre Nonell had a studio in the building. Picasso used the studio until he finally moved to Paris in April 1904.

8. Llotja de Barcelona, Carrer del Consolat del Mar

***

Picasso entered the School of Fine Arts (Escola de Llotja) in 1895 aged 13, where his father was also a teacher of drawing. At the time, the Fine Arts School occupied the top floor of the neoclassical building. In 1897 parents later sent him to the Royal Academy of San Fernando art school in Madrid, the most prestigious school of art in the country at the time. He disliked the formal academic teaching methods at San Fernando however and quickly stopped attending classes. He focused his attention on the great masters such as Diego Vel√°zquez and Francisco Goya, whose work he was able to see at the Prado Museum. Picasso left Madrid for the village of Horta de Sant Joan near Tarragona to stay with his friend Manuel Pallar√©s. He later told his biographer Jaime Sabart√©s ‚Äòeverything I know, I learnt in Pallar√©s‚Äô village‚Äô.

9. Els Quatre Gats (Carrer de Montsi√≥, 3)

***

Els Quatre Gats was founded by Pere Romeu, Ramon Casas, Santiago Rusinol, Miquel Utrillo and others in 1897, in imitation of Rodolphe Salis‚Äôs Parisian cabaret, Le Chat Noir. It‚Äôs original purpose was for holding gatherings of artists and as a concert and exhibition hall. It is situated in a modernist building designed by Puig i Cadafalch. Picasso painted the menu and his first ever public exhibition was held there in February 1900.

10. Sala Par√©s (Carrer de Petritxol, 5)

***

Sala Par√©s is where Picasso presented his first commercial gallery exhibition in 1901 at the age of 20. The gallery put on an exhibition of pastel drawings by Picasso jointly with Ramon Casas. One of the oldest art galleries in the world, Sala Par√©s has been located at Carrer de Petritxol, 5 in the Gothic Quarter since 1884.

Pla√ßa de l‚ÄôOli, 4

Joan Vidal i Ventosa‚Äôs studio, known as el Guayaba was a meeting place for artists situated in La Ribera neighborhood. The building on Placa de L‚ÄôOli was later demolished due to the opening of the Via Laietana. This photo shows Fernande Oliver, Picasso and Ram√≥n Ravent√≥s at el Guayaba in 1906. That year Picasso spent a summer in the village of G√≥sol in the Pyrenees with Fernande.

11. Col¬∑legi d‚ÄôArquitectes de Catalunya (Pla√ßa Nova, 5)

***

The friezes on the facade of the Col¬∑legi d‚ÄôArquitectes de Catalunya were created by the Norwegian artist, Carl Nesjar in 1960 from drawings made by Picasso. There are three friezes on the exterior of the building, depicting different scenes. On the Carrer Capellans side (pictured above), the frieze depicts the Cors de Clav√©, the groups from the hermitage of Sant Medir and the ‚Äúfauns‚Äù of Arrabassada and Les Planes.

12. Museu Picasso (Carrer de Montcada, 15-23)

***

The Museu Picasso occupies five buildings on Carrer Montcada in the El Born neighborhood. It opened in the Aguilar palace in 1963, exhibiting the private collection of Jaime Sabart√©s and the collection of Picasso‚Äôs work held in the art museums of Barcelona. The exhibits were later expanded with important donations by Picasso himself and the museum annexed the palace of the Baron of Castellet to accommodate them. Jacqueline Roque and Picasso‚Äôs heirs also donated works, which lead to the Meca palace being annexed in 1985. Casa Mauri and the Finestres palace were opened in 1999, in order to display temporary exhibitions. Picasso never saw the museum, having vowed to never set foot again in Spain while Franco was still in power.

13. Passeig de Colom, 22

The Ranzini hotel was located at 22 Passeig de Colom and is where Ukrainian ballet dancer Olga Khoklova, Picasso‚Äôs future first wife, stayed in 1917. Picasso stayed at his family‚Äôs home at 3 Carrer de la Merc√®, but painted the view from Olga‚Äôs balcony when he visited. (See: Passeig de Colom. Barcelona, 1917)

14. Carrer d‚ÄôAviny√≥ 44

***

One of Picasso‚Äôs most renowned paintings, Les Demoiselles d‚ÄôAvignon, on display at the Museum of Modern Art (MoMA) in New York City, is understood to make reference to a brothel on Carrer d‚ÄôAviny√≥ in the Gothic Quarter. The large oil painting is described by MoMA as ‚Äòone of the most important works in the genesis of modern art‚Äô.

Tribute to Picasso by Antoni Tapies

***

Commissioned by Barcelona‚Äôs city council in 1981, the Tribute to Picasso is an assemblage of modernist furniture reminiscent of the period in which Picasso lived in the city. It is situated on Passeig de Picasso next to Parc de la Ciutadella.

White sheets inside the cube have quotations by Picasso written on them in Catalan, notably the following;

‚Äúa painting is not intended to decorate a drawing room but is instead a weapon of attack and defence against the enemy‚Äù
